items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
Further light rainfall is forecast throughout Friday but no further flooding is expected.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels remain high but have been falling at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Consequently, the risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads continues. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map. This message will be updated after 17:00 today, 13/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall over the past weekend. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.

Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road and Sileby Mill road, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes.

No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high for the next 24 hours.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

This message will be updated by 17:00 tomorrow, 13/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on sections of the River Churn following recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue over the next few days, especially in the Cerney Wick area. The weather forecast is for light drizzle throughout Friday with some showers overnight into early Saturday morning. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 14/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high but are falling on the lower River Cherwell. Flooding of roads and low-lying land remains possible today, 12/12/2024, especially in the Thrupp area. The weather forecast is for showers on Thursday. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high on the River Windrush. The flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue, especially around Bourton-on-the-Water and near the confluence with the River Thames. The weather forecast is for light drizzle throughout Friday with some showers overnight into early Saturday morning. Water levels will remain high over the next few days. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 14/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are low on the River Evenlode but remain high on the River Glyme. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue along the River Glyme in the Woodstock area. The weather forecast is for showers on Thursday. 
We are monitoring the situation. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message:
Property flooding is not expected. River levels remain high but have started to fall. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible in the areas around Abingdon and Culham. The weather forecast is for showers on Thursday. 
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high but continue to fall gradually on the Ginge Brook. We expect this to continue over the coming days. The weather forecast is for showers on Thursday. 
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high but are now dropping on the Lower River Cherwell and River Ray. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue. Property flooding is not expected. The weather forecast is for showers on Thursday. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and its small tributaries from Calcutt to Lechlade

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Blunsdon Brook, Water Eaton Brook, Marston Meysey Brook, Share Ditch, Bydemill Brook, Westrop Brook, Downington Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels continue dropping on the River Thames and other local watercourses. We expect the gradual decrease to continue over the coming days. The flooding of roads and low lying land remains possible. The weather forecast is for showers on Thursday. 
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Nene

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Nene has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels along the River Thame are falling. Levels remain high in the lower reaches, especially in the Stadhampton and Dorchester areas. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 12/12/2024 around those areas. The weather forecast is for showers on Thursday. 
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels remain high on the Lower River Avon and its tributaries. High ground water will keep river levels high. 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.
The forecast is for no further rain in the next 24 hours.
We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels.
Please consider activating any property flood protection products and start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are high and will continue to remain high for several days as water from Storm Darragh flows into the Hundred Foot Washes. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. This information is correct as of  07:30am on Friday 13th December. The causeway at Earith may now have some water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 56 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 65 centimetres of water on the road. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the road at Welney. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. We will update this message by 4 pm today, Friday 13th December 2024.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are slowly falling but remain high on the Lower Colne, Friday 13th December.
Flooding to low lying land and roads may continue to affect locations near the River Colne, Frays, Wraysbury, Poyle Channel, Staines Moor and Longford today.
The forecast is mostly dry but the levels on the Lower River Colne are expected to remain high for several days. 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated by 6pm Friday 13th December, or sooner if the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Tern – Walcot and Rodington river gauges. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. 

Showers are possible today but rainfall is not forecast to be significant. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 09:00 on Saturday, 14/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but flowing within banks on the River Dikler. The weather forecast is for light drizzle throughout Friday with some showers overnight into early Saturday morning. We expect water levels to remain high over the coming days. 
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 14/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the River Leach but are dropping steadily. The flooding of low-lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially around Lechlade. The weather forecast is for light drizzle throughout Friday with some showers overnight into early Saturday morning. 
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 14/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are now starting to fall slowly on the Chertsey Bourne following heavy rainfall last week. No further flooding of low lying land and roads is expected. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to continue to fall  slowly.  We will continue to monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 14/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: B1040 Thorney to Whittlesey Road to the South of the River Nene
items.message: River levels in the Peterborough area remain high on the River Nene due to recent heavy rainfall. The Whittlesey Wash flood storage reservoir is being operated to protect nearby communities from flooding. The rising levels in the Wash will result in flooding of the B1040 road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority may close the B1040 for safety reasons. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated on Friday 13th December, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message: River levels remain high following continued rainfall from Storm Darragh. Flooding is possible over the next few days as floodwater flows down the River Great Ouse from upstream. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly. Access to properties in Berry Lane, Godmanchester, may also be affected. The forecast is now dry, which will allow levels to start falling later this week. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don’t put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 6pm today, Friday 13th December 2024.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Central Bedfordshire, Beds Borough and Cambridgeshire from Wyboston to Brampton
Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message:
Flooding is possible as the Lower River Frome and its tributaries, remain high though river levels are slowly falling.  Increased ground water is also keeping rivers high. No further rain is predicted
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Please consider activating any property flood protection products and start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of Storm Darragh.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.    

Showers are possible today but rainfall is not forecast to be significant.  River levels are falling slowly, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.   

This message will be updated 09:00 on Saturday, 14/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle River Great Ouse in Milton Keynes, Bedford Borough and Central Bedfordshire
River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.00m and is slowly falling. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.39m and is slowly falling. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m and the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m. The roads from Muchelney to Thorney and from Muchelney to Draycott, Law Lane, are not affected. Property flooding at this time is not expected.

The forecast for the next five days is for dry weather with no significant rain forecast. We will continue to pump water from the moors during this dry spell.

We will continue to monitor the situation, clearing weed screens and checking rivers for blockages. Don't put yourself or others at risk. For further details, please search for Somerset emergency road closure. This message will be updated by 2PM on 13/12/2024 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Stour
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Great Stour, East Stour, Aylesford Stream, Ruckinge Dyke, Whitewater Dyke, Stour

items.message: River levels remain high, but are gradually receding in the Ashford area, today Friday 13/12/2024, as a result of rainfall last week. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible today 13/12/2024, property flooding is not expected. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near roads and rivers in the Ashford area. No further significant rainfall is forecast but river levels will remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are prepared to respond if required. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated this afternoon 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Tewkesbury, Upper Pound river gauge because of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. 

Tewkesbury Upper Pound 4.11m 11/12/24 and Mythe 4.12m 11/12/2024. 

No significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday, 14/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Avon in Worcestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall very slowly at the Bredon river gauge because of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning and the Eckington Road.  

Observed peaks:- Evesham: 2.22m on Sunday 08/12/2024. Bredon: 2.69m on Tuesday 10/12/24.  

No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please avoid low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated by 6pm on Friday, 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries from Buscot Wick down to Kings Lock
items.message:
Further property flooding is not expected. River levels are falling on the River Thames. However, flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible. River levels are expected to continue a gradual fall over the coming days. The weather forecast is for showers on Thursday. 
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels remain high due to the rainfall associated with Storm Darragh. Areas most at risk include local roads and low-lying land around Thornton Lock, Stamford Bridge, Buttercrambe and Elvington. No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days and levels are expected to fall slowly over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00pm on Friday, 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message:
No further property flooding is expected. River levels are falling slowly in the Oxford area. Flooding of low-lying land and roads remains possible. The weather forecast is for showers on Thursday. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels remain high in response to the rainfall associated with Storm Darragh. Areas most at risk are the Upper Derwent area, including the low lying land around the Low Marishes, Old Malton, and Priorpot Beck in Norton. No further significant rainfall is expected in the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. The flood warning for Old Malton has been removed and pumping operations continue in Malton. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00pm on Friday 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
River levels continue to fall steadily at the Cae Howel river gauge following Storm Darragh.  However, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley.  

No significant rainfall is forecast over the next few days. River levels are falling but may still pose a flood risk. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defenses and clearing weed screens. 

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 09:00 on Saturday, 14/12/2024, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Teme
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.   

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further significant rainfall is forecast.   

We continue to monitor the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: River Sow and River Penk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
The flooding of low-lying land and roads near the River Tone and on Currymoor continues during Thursday, 12/12/2024. Cutts Road remains closed, but New Road may soon be reopened. Please search for Somerset emergency road closure before travelling.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 6.99 and is stable. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir, via Hookbridge spillway, if this level exceeds 7.45m. However, this is not expected. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.89m and is falling.

We will continue to pump water from the moors at Currymoor, Northmoor, Saltmoor and Stanmoor pumping stations when required.

The forecast for the next five days is for dry weather with no significant rain forecast.

We continue to pump water and check our flood defences and rivers for blockages. Don't put yourself or others at risk and do not drive or cycle through floodwater.

This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester
items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Dee but are slowly falling. No further rain is expected before the weekend. 
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington.
Townfield Lane is expected to remain cut off until Sunday. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Worcestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high bu8t are falling steadily at the Worcester and Diglis gauges due to recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations affected are Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke and Upton upon Severn. Install property level protection if required. 

Observed peaks:- Bewdley 4.51m 10/12/24, Worcester 4.96m 11/12/2024, Kempsey Yacht Club 6.53m 11/12/24, Saxons Lode 4.89m 11/12/24.

No significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday, 14/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Kempsey Village
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling steadily at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge due to recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and Squires Walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey.  

Kempsey Flood Alleviation Scheme is currently operational. 

Observed Peak:- Kempsey Yacht Club 6.53m 11/12/2024.  

No significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday, 14/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent in Derbyshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: River Severn in Shropshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.   

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further significant rainfall is forecast.   

We continue to monitor the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: River Severn at Severn Ham, Tewkesbury
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling steadily at the Mythe Bridge river gauge due to recent rainfall. We expect flooding to continue to affect properties and roads in and around Severn Ham, Tewkesbury.  

Observed peaks:- Mythe 4.12m and Tewkesbury Upper Pound 4.11m on 11/12/2024.  

No significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please avoid low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated by 11am Saturday, 14/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Court Meadow, Kempsey and Callow End
River Severn at Apperley and The Leigh
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling steadily at the Haw Bridge river gauge due to recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect Gabb Lane at Apperley and local caravan parks. 
Observed peak at Haw Bridge 4.93m Wednesday 11/12/2024. 

No significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. 

This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday, 14/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Hanley Road, Upton upon Severn
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
The risk of flooding from Storm Darragh has now reduced.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.  No significant rainfall is expected over the next few days. 
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to slowly rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. 

The forecast is for no further rainfall and we expect levels to stabilise and then recede

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to slowly rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. No further rainfall is expected and groundwater levels are predicted to level off soon.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Piddle and tributaries
items.message:
River levels remain high, but are now slowly dropping. Increased ground water is keeping levels high.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Piddle, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.
The forecast for the next 24 hours is for no further significant rain.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and checking rivers for blockages.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for Shiplake, Lower Shiplake and Wargrave
River Thames from Mapledurham to Sonning
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high, but are falling, on the River Thames. Flooding of low-lying land and roads is expected to continue in areas of Sonning closest to the river. The weather forecast is for showers on Thursday. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Pangbourne to Purley
items.message: Property flooding is not expected. River levels are falling slowly on this section of the River Thames. The flooding of low-lying land and roads will continue today, 12/12/2024, in the Pangbourne area.  The weather forecast is for showers on Thursday. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and its tributaries from Days Lock to above Pangbourne

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Lady Brook, Ewelme Stream, Mill Brook, West Hagbourne Stream, Hakkas Brook, Cholsey Brook, Kibble Ditch

items.message: Property flooding is not expected. River levels have peaked on this section of the Thames and are falling slowly. The flooding of low-lying land and roads remains possible, especially in areas closest to the River Thames around Goring. The weather forecast is for showers on Thursday. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Hurley to Cookham
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but starting to fall slowly on the River Thames following a period of sustained rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, 13/12/2024, especially in the Marlow area. No further rainfall is forecast and we expect levels to fall slowly. We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 14/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for Henley, Remenham, Medmenham and its tributaries

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Oxfordshire, Windsor and Maidenhead, Wokingham
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Assendon Stream, Hambledon Brook

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to slowly rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. No further rainfall is expected and we expect groundwater levels to stop rising soon.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are falling but remain high following rainfall from Storm Darragh. Flooding of low-lying land is possible. Areas most at risk are those around the River Rhee from Guilden Morden to Haslingfield. The forecast is now dry, which will allow levels to continue to fall. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don’t put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 6pm today, Friday 13th December.

items.description: River Coln and its tributaries
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but stable on the River Coln and tributaries. Flooding of low-lying land and roads is still expected in the Fossebridge area. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. The weather forecast is for light drizzle throughout Friday with some showers overnight into early Saturday morning.
We are monitoring the situation. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 14/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Derwent at Buttercrambe Mill
items.message: River levels continue to fall slowly. No further rainfall is expected. Forecasts indicate that river levels will continue to fall slowly, but this warning is likely to remain in place for the next couple of days, until levels have fallen sufficiently. We continue to monitor river levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 4:00pm on Friday 13/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Derwent at Stamford Bridge - The Weir Caravan Park and Kexby Bridge

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: This flood warning has been removed as levels on the river Derwent have fallen below the level where property flooding is expected.  The wider flood alert for the lower river Derwent remains in force.  Please continue to exercise caution on low lying footpaths and roads.

items.description: Little Ouse River and River Thet in Suffolk and Norfolk
items.message: River levels have peaked at Redbridge and remain high downstream following rainfall from Storm Darragh. Flooding of low lying land is possible.  Areas most at risk are those around the Little Ouse River from Rickinghall to Hockwold, including The Black Bourn, and River Thet from Attleborough to Thetford. The forecast for this week is dry, which will allow levels to start falling. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 6pm today, Friday 13th December 2024.

items.description: River Derwent at Old Malton
items.message: This flood warning has been removed as levels on the river Derwent have fallen below the level where property flooding is expected.  The wider flood alert for the upper river Derwent remains in force and pumping operations continue in Malton.  Please continue to exercise caution on low lying footpaths and roads

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message: Groundwater levels are currently rising at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area as a result of persistent rainfall. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few weeks. We expect levels to continue to rise over the coming weeks and levels remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore  be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 17/12/2024 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message: Groundwater levels are currently rising at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley as a result of persistent rainfall. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next week. We expect levels to rise over coming weeks and levels remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, 17/12/2024 or as the situation changes.
